module.p: bho from is the (leniting) ablative preposition.

section.p:
The default form of the ablative preposition is simply bho –
bho thaigh from a house
bho aislingean from dreams
bho Nirribhidh from Norway
bho thrì làithean from three days
Note that all forms of the ablative preposition can be spelled without the initial bh- ie. o, on, om, uam, ...

When the immediately following word is a singular form of the definite article, the linking form bhon is used –
bhon an taigh from the house
bhon a’ bhaile from the town But –
bho na h-aislingean from the dreams, rather than bhon na h-aislingean
Note that bhon an and bhon a’ often reduce to just bhon – bhon taigh, bhon bhaile.

Fused forms are sometimes found when the immediately following word is a possessive determiner –
bho mo thaigh from my house ≈ bhom thaigh
bho do bhaile from your town ≈ bhod bhaile
bho a h-òran from her song ≈ bho h-òran
bho a chraoibh from his tree ≈ bho chraoibh
bho ar n-achadh from our field ≈ bhar n-achadh
bho ur leapannan from your beds ≈ bhur leapannan
bho an taighean from their houses ≈ bhon taighean
bho am baile from their town ≈ bhom baile
Note that these fused forms are rather awkward and sometimes ambiguous and hence are best avoided in writing nowadays.

Conjugated prepositions are used in place of bho mi, bho thu, ... , bho iad –
bhuam from me
bhuat from you
bhuaipe from her/it
bhuaithe from him/it
bhuainn from us
bhuaibh from you
bhuapa from them

There are also emphatic forms (cf. bho mise, bho thusa, ... , bho iadsan) –
bhuamsa from me
bhuatsa from you
bhuaipese from her/it
bhuaithe-san from him/it
bhuainne from us
bhuaibhse from you
bhuapasan from them

Finally, there are also reflexive forms (cf. bho mi fhìn, bho thu fhèin, ... , bho iad fhèin) –
bhuam fhìn from myself
bhuat fhèin from yourself
bhuaipe fhèin from herself/itself
bhuaithe fhèin from himself/itself
bhuainn fhìn from ourselves
bhuaibh fhèin from yourselves
bhuapa fhèin from themselves

module.p:
thig bho ... come from somewhere –
Examples from Gairm –
Bha grunnan de ar luchd-leughaidh an dùil, nuair a nochd an àireamh mu dheireadh de Ghairm, gu robh sin a’ strì ri buidheann shònraichte, no duine sònraichte, a chur do ’n Phàrlamaid, agus bha wèireichean an telefon gu math teth, uair no dhà, an déidh dhuinn tighinn o ’n chlò. Thog iad ceàrr sinn.
Some of our readers were expecting [?], when the last issue of Gairm appeared, that that was striving to send a particular group [party?], or a particular person, to the Parliament, and the telephone wires were pretty hot,for an hour or two [once or twice?], after we came from the printers. They misunderstood us. td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’
